Novel octanuclear copper(I) clusters [Cu8{(N)-(μ4-S)}4(μ3-I)2I2(PPh3)2] produced via reductive S-S bond cleavage of disulfide Schiff base ligands and their use as efficient heterogeneous catalysts in CuAAC click reaction Saeedeh Asadizadeh Conceptualization Investigation Writing – original draft a Marzieh Sohrabi Conceptualization Investigation Software a Kurt Mereiter Investigation Writing – review & editing b ⁎ Hossein Farrokhpour Formal analysis Writing – review & editing Software a Soraia Meghdadi Conceptualization Supervision Investigation a Mehdi Amirnasr Conceptualization Supervision Writing – review & editing a ⁎ a Department of Chemistry, Isfahan University of Technology, Isfahan 8415683111, Iran Department of Chemistry Isfahan University of Technology Isfahan 8415683111 Iran aDepartment of Chemistry, Isfahan University of Technology, Isfahan 8415683111, Iran b Faculty of Chemistry, Vienna University of Technology, Getreidemarkt 9/164SC, A-1060 Vienna, Austria Faculty of Chemistry Vienna University of Technology Getreidemarkt 9/164SC, A-1060 Vienna Austria bFaculty of Chemistry, Vienna University of Technology, Getreidemarkt 9/164SC, A-1060 Vienna, Austria ⁎ Corresponding authors. Thiol/disulfide interconversion, catalyzed by metal ions and enzymes, is a fundamental transformation and plays important roles in biological systems. The thiolates, produced in these reactions, are particularly versatile sulfur-containing ligands that can bind to metals or group of metals via a variety of modes and this versatility can lead to the formation of polymeric chains and metal clusters with high nuclearity. Herein, we report the facile one pot synthesis of novel octanuclear copper(I) complexes, [Cu8{(N)-(μ4-S)}4(μ3-I)2I2(PPh3)2] (1–5), by the reaction of copper(I) iodide and disulfide Schiff base molecules (R-CHN˗Ph˗S˗S˗Ph-NCH-R, RMePh = 4-MePh (SB1), RMeOPh = 4-MeOPh (SB2), RMeSPh = 4-MeSPh (SB3), RBrPh = 4-BrPh (SB4), and RFur = 2-furan (SB5)) in the presence of PPh3 in dichloromethane-acetonitrile or chloroform-acetonitrile solution under ambient conditions. Single-crystal X-ray structure analyses of these clusters confirm the presence of Cu8S4I4 core stabilized by the chelating Schiff base thiolate fragment R-CHN˗Ph˗Sˉ produced by the reductive cleavage of disulfide bond, Iˉ, and PPh3. DFT calculations have been performed to describe a speculative mechanism of cluster formation. The octanuclear clusters [Cu8{(N)-(μ4-S)}4(μ3-I)2I2(PPh3)2] (1–5) have been exploited as efficient heterogeneous catalysts for the green synthesis of 1,2,3-triazoles from NaN3, alkyl halides, and alkyne derivatives (CuAAC reaction) under mild conditions. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Novel octanuclear Cu(I) clusters Crystal structures Heterogeneous catalysis CuAAC click reaction Synthesis of 1,2,3-triazoles Abbreviations CuAAC Copper-catalyzedazidealkyne cycloaddition SB Schiff base Phds 2,2'-diaminodiphenyl disulphide (SN)- Schiff base thiolate CuOAc Copper acetate PPh3 Triphenylphosphine Et2O Diethyl ether CDCl3 Deuterated chloroform Me4Si Tetramethylsilane THF Tertahydrofuran TBAH Tetrabutylammoniumhexafluorophosphate ACN Acetonitrile rt Room temperature MLCT Metal-to-ligand charge transfer DFT Density functional theory PCM Polarizable continuum model TS Transition state QST Quadratic synchronous transit CV Cyclic voltammetry TLC Thin Layer Chromatography ESI Electronic Supplementary Information 1 Introduction The structural diversity, exceptional optical properties, and remarkable catalytic activity of polynuclear d10 metal complexes, and group 11 in particular, have been the focus of intense investigation in the past few years. Several excellent publications and reviews have discussed the design, synthesis, structure, and properties of coinage metal clusters with varying coordination arrangements stabilized mainly by thiolate, dithiocarbamate, and phospine ligands [1–8]. The extension of this chemistry is highly desirable owing to the potential application of structurally well defined, and stable metal clusters in the fields of optics, electronics, sensing, medicine, and catalysis [9–22]. Among the coinage metals, copper is abundant, inexpensive and stands out as a metal of choice from an economic point of view. In addition, copper clusters play vital roles in biological systems [23–26] and catalytic organic transformations [27–29]. Compounds containing copper chalcogenide clusters can be synthesized by various approaches. The nuclearity, stability, and functionality of the resulting clusters vary significantly with subtle changes in the synthetic parameters [30–33]. In a pioneering paper, Fuhr and co-workers have reported the synthesis and crystal structures of luminescent polynuclear copper(I) phenyl thiolate clusters, prepared by the reaction of CuOAc with p-Me3SiS–C6H4–NMe2 in the presence of the corresponding phosphine. While [Cu4(p-S-C6H4 NMe2)4(dppm)2], is synthesized in the presence of 0.5 eq dppm in DMF, [Cu4(p-S–C6H4–NMe2)4(PPh3)4] and [Cu7(p-S-C6H4 NMe2)7(PPh3)4] are prepared utilizing 4 equiv. of PPh3 in Et2O and 1 equiv. of PPh3 in THF respectively [32]. In a recent well-designed work by Straub and co-workers on the copper-catalyzed azide–alkyne cycloaddition (CuAAC), the existence of an octacopper(I) hexaacetylide cluster as a precatalyst has been documented [34]. Recent fascinating aspects of CuAAC click reaction and its applications have been elegantly discussed by leading scholars in several papers and review articles [34–42]. It seems highly desirable to develop stable metal clusters with high catalytic performances in CuAAC reaction under mild conditions. In this context we herein report the facile one pot synthesis, characterization, and crystal structures of octanuclear copper(I) clusters (1–5), Table 1 , obtained by the reaction of disulfide containing Schiff base molecules (RCHN-PhS˗)2 (SB1-SB5 ) Scheme 1 , with CuI in the presence of PPh3. A speculative mechanism of cluster formation is presented and verified by DFT calculations. Successful application of these cluster complexes as heterogeneous catalysts in the efficient and green synthesis of 1,2,3-triazoles with high yield, good selectivity, and with no byproducts, under mild water-tolerant conditions is reported and discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and methods All solvents and chemicals were of commercial reagent grade and used as received from Aldrich and Merck. Infrared spectra using KBr pellets were collected on a FT-IR JASCO 680 plus spectrometer in the range 4000–400 cm–1. UV–vis absorption spectra were recorded on a JASCO V-570 spectrophotometer. Melting points were determined with a Büchi instrument. 1H NMR spectra were measured with a Bruker AVANCE III 400 spectrometer (400 MHz). Proton chemical shifts are reported in ppm relative to Me4Si as internal standard. Elemental analyses were performed by using a Perkin–Elmer 2400II CHNS–O elemental analyzer. Electrochemical properties of Cu8 clusters (1–5) were studied by cyclic voltammetry. Cyclic voltammograms were recorded by a SAMA 500 Research Analyzer using a three–electrode system, a glassy carbon working electrode (Metrohm 6.1204.110 with 2.0 ± 0.1 mm diameter), a platinum disk auxiliary electrode and Ag wire as reference electrode. CV measurements were performed in CDCl3 with tetrabutylammonium hexafluorophosphate (TBAH) as supporting electrolyte. 2.2 Synthesis of the Schiff base molecules (SB1-SB5) A methanolic solution of the aldehyde, R-CHO (2 mmol in 5 mL) was added to a solution of 2,2′-diaminodiphenyl disulfide, Phds, in methanol (1 mmol in 5 mL) with continuous stirring. The mixture was stirred for a few hours and the resulting yellowish powder was isolated by filtration and washed with cold methanol. The products were characterized by CHNS elemental analyses (Table S1) and different spectroscopic methods (see ESI for details). 2.3 Characterization (SB1). Reaction time: 5 h. Yield 85%. Dark purple crystals. Yield of 35% (based on CuI). Anal. calcd for (Cu8C62H47N4S4O4P2I4): C, 35.15; H, 2.24; N, 2.64; S, 6.05. Found: C, 35.36; H, 2.15; N, 2.43; S, 6.34%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 1590 (m, C=N), 883 (m, C-S). UV–vis: λ max (nm) (ɛ, mol−1 L cm−1) (chloroform): 500 (7200), 304 (70,500), 256 (87,000). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 300 MHz), δ (ppm) = 6.49–8.05 (m, 58H, ArH), 8.30 (s, 2H, Himine), 8.33 (s, 2H, Himine). 2.6 X-ray crystal structure determination of the copper complexes 1–4 For X-ray diffraction crystals of the copper complexes 1–4 were used as obtained from synthesis. The crystals were measured at T = 100 K on Bruker CCD diffractometers using Mo-Kα radiation. The recorded frame data were processed for reflection intensities corrected for absorption. The structures were solved by direct methods and were refined by full-matrix least-squares on F2 using the SHELX suite of computer programs [43]. The crystals of complexes 1, 2 and 3 contained solvent molecules in substoichiometric amounts. The crystals of 1, 2 and 4 showed partial vacancies for two terminal CuI moieties of the octanuclear Cu-clusters. Further details on the crystal structure determinations and the crystallographic data are reported in the ESI (Table S2 and Tables S3–1 to S3–4) while salient results are presented below (Section 3.2). 2.7 Computational methodology All calculations were performed using Gaussian 09 quantum chemistry package [44]. All structures were optimized using density functional theory (DFT) employing B3LYP functional in the acetonitrile solvent. The 6–311+G(2d,p) basis set and the relativistic effective core pseudo potential LANL2DZ [45–47], were selected for (C, N, H and S atoms) and (Cu and I) atoms, respectively. The intrinsic reaction coordinate (IRC) calculations were performed at the same level of theory. The polarized continuum model (PCM) according to the self-consistent reaction field method reported by Tomasi et al. [48–50], was used for modeling the solvent in the calculations. 2.8 Catalytic activity of Cu8 clusters in CuAAC reaction The catalytic test reactions were carried out in water and by mixing NaN3, the alkyl halide, alkyne derivative and the catalyst, with stirring at room temperature. The reaction progress was monitored by TLC until complete consumption of the azide. After drying the reaction mixture under aerobic conditions, the product was separated by extraction using ethyl acetate. The solid product was obtained by slow evaporation of the solvent and then purified by re-crystallization in chloroform and finally characterized. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization The disulfide Schiff base molecules SB1-SB5 (Scheme 1) were synthesized by the condensation of 2,2′-diaminodiphenyl disulfide, Phds, with 4-R’-benzaldehyde (R’ = Me, MeO, MeS, Br) and furfuraldehyde respectively. Conversion of disulfide to thiol occurs by a variety of redox reagents, enzymes, and electrochemical methods [51–53]. The general rout envisioned for the synthesis of [Cu8{(N)-(μ4-S)}4(μ3-I)2I2(PPh3)2] clusters (1, 2, 3, 4, 5), is presented in Scheme 2 . The water is provided by the solvents which are used without being dried, or by adding an appropriate amount of water. The plausible mechanism of S-S bond cleavage and cluster formation is presented in the theoretical section (vide infra). Formation of Cu6(SC5H4N)6 cluster, and copper(I) inorganic/organic hybrid networks, [Cu5(SCN)3(2-pyt)2], and [Cu4I4(2-pytH)] through S-S cleavage of 2,2´-dithiopyridine under hydrothermal conditions have been reported [54,55]. The synthesized octanuclear clusters, with supporting NS-thiol-donor ligands (generated in-situ by S-S bond cleavage at room temperature), were characterized by elemental analyses, UV–vis and FT-IR spectroscopy (please see the ESI for the details). The cleavage of S–S bond is supported by single crystal X-ray diffraction (vide infra). The IR bands at about 1590 cm–1 and 820 cm–1 are assigned to C=N and C–S stretching vibrations of the coordinated thiolate Schiff base (Figs. S2.1.1–S2.5.1 in ESI) [56,57]. Room temperature (chloroform solution) UV–vis absorption band at about 450 nm is due to MLCT (Fig. S2.1.2–S2.5.2 in ESI). This transition is characteristic of copper(I) Schiff base complexes and conforms to the red color of these clusters in solution [58]. Direct evidence for the clean formation of Cu(I) octanuclear clusters comes from 1H NMR and cyclic voltammetry. The 1H NMR spectra of 1–5 are characteristic of diamagnetic copper(I) complexes exhibiting sharp proton signals {at 2.48 (s, 12H, CH3), 5.50–8.50 (m, 62H, ArH and 4H, Himine) for 1; 4.16 (s, 12H, OCH3), 6.36–7.93 (m, 62H, ArH) and 7.96 (s, 4H, Himine) for 2; 2.87 (s, 12H, S-CH3), 6.42–7.83 (m, 62H, ArH), 7.88 (s, 4H, Himine) for 3; 6.52–8.13 (m, 62H, ArH), 8.24, 8.45 (2 s, 4H, Himine) for 4; 6.49–8.05 (m, 58H, ArH), 8.30 (s, 2H, Himine), 8.33 (s, 2H, Himine) for 5}. (Figs. S2.1.3–S2.5.3 in ESI for details). The cyclic voltammograms of all four clusters exhibit a one electron oxidation of copper(I) centers to copper(II) in 1.02–1.27 V range [4] (Figs. S2.1.4–S2.5.4 in ESI). 3.2 X-ray crystal structures of the complexes (1–4) The X-ray crystal structure analysis revealed that complex 1 co-crystallized with CH3CN and CH2Cl2 in a monoclinic lattice of space group P21/n and that the Cu-cluster is centrosymmetric. Complex 2 co-crystallized with CHCl3 in a monoclinic lattice of space group P21/n, but here the Cu-cluster is asymmetric. Complex 3 co-crystallized with CHCl3 in a triclinic lattice of space group P1̄, built up from two crystallographically independent, but geometrically similar and centrosymmetric Cu-clusters. Complex 4 crystallized without solvent in a monoclinic lattice of space group C2/c with a centrosymmetric Cu-cluster. Despite these differences the cores of all Cu complexes have the same topology and display similar bond lengths and other geometric features. Therefore, the structural main features are discussed here for complexes 1 and 2, whereas further details for all complexes are outlined in the ESI. A view of the molecular structure of complex 1 is shown in Fig. 1 , whereas in Fig. 2 the complex is stripped of all carbon atoms. The core of the complex (Fig. 2) can be visualized as a very distorted open cube of eight Cu(I) centers, where four of the six Cu4 faces of the cube are capped by the S atoms of four Schiff base ligands in μ4-fashion, while two Cu4 faces are capped by a iodo-ligand in a μ3-fashion with a long non-bonding distance to the fourth Cu (e.g. I1 to Cu4i, Fig. 2). There are three types of Cu(I) centers in the [Cu8{(N)-(μ4-S)}4(μ3-I)2I2(PPh3)2] core: a) Cu1, Cu2 and their inversion related equivalents Cu1i and Cu2i with a tetrahedral 4-coordination by two S, one I, and one N atom; b) Cu3 and Cu3i with a tetrahedral 4-coordination by two S, one I, and one P; and c) Cu4 and Cu4i with a planar 3-coordination by two S and one exo-oriented terminal iodide (I2, I2i). The four Schiff base thiolates (NS)− act as bridging ligands. The Cu-S bonds are quite uniform and in the range of 2.320 to 2.403 Å, mean value 2.360 Å (all numbers rounded, for e.s.d.’s see ESI), giving each sulfur a pyramidal 5-coordination by 4 Cu and the carbon atom of the Schiff base (S1-C10 = 1.768 Å, S2-C24 = 1.770 Å). The N atoms of the chelating Schiff base ligands show a flat 3-cordination by one Cu (Cu1-N1 = 2.045 Å, Cu2-N2 = 2.062 Å) and two carbon atoms with N1-C1 and N2-C15 as formal double bonds (1.294 Å and 1.287 Å). The μ3-bonded iodide I1 shows two short Cu-I bonds of 2.638 and 2.640 Å to Cu1 and Cu2, and an intermediate bond Cu3-I1 = 2.865 Å. The distance I1-Cu4i = 3.351 Å is regarded as non-bonding because the 3-coordination of Cu4 by S1, S2 and I2 is flat. In agreement with this consideration the corresponding I-Cu distances in complexes 2, 3, and 4 vary distinctly between 3.235 and 3.551 Å. The bond between Cu4 and the terminal iodide I2, 2.469 Å, can be regarded as a single bond and is shorter than in mononuclear (PPh3)2CuI (2.536 Å) [59]. The bond Cu3-P1 = 2.235 Å compares well with other Cu(I)-phosphine complexes [59]. Like many polynuclear Cu(I) compounds the complexes in 1–4 exhibit short Cu•••Cu distances which may be considered as cuprophilic interactions [60–63]. The cuprophilic Cu•••Cu interactions in 1 are most pronounced between Cu1 and Cu2i, 2.689 Å, followed by Cu1•••Cu3 = 2.748 Å and Cu3•••Cu2 = 2.822 Å; they and their centrosymmetric equivalents define a six-membered ring of Cu atoms with a chair conformation. Cu3•••Cu4 = 2.921 Å is already above the frequently used limit of 2.8 Å for cuprophilic interactions. The two independent Schiff base ligands are notably twisted and show interplanar angles between the phenyl rings C2 through C7 and C9 through C14 of 68.7°, and 57.8° between the phenyl rings C16 through C21 and C23 through C28. Each two adjacent ligands exhibit a head-to-tail arrangement and adjacent phenyl rings show slipped π-π stacking interactions with ring-ring angles of 8.1 and 3.5° (C9-C14 with C16i-C21i and C2-C9 with C23i-C28i, respectively) and ring-ring separations of about 3.4 Å. An additional π-π interaction exists between ring C9-C14 and one phenyl ring (C35-C40) of the PPh3 ligand (Fig. 1). Disregarding the phenyl rings of PPh3 the [Cu8{(N)-(μ4-S)}4(μ3-I)2I2P2] moiety in 1 is not only centrosymmetric, but approaches a molecular (but not a reticular) point symmetry 2/m quite well with Cu3, Cu4, I1, I2 and P1 on the mirror plane and the twofold axis passing through the midpoints between the atom pairs Cu1/Cu2i and Cu1i/Cu2 (Fig. 2). In this way the two independent Schiff base ligands with their head-to-tail arrangement about the 2-fold axis become approximately pseudo-equivalent. On a molecular basis the phenyl rings of PPh3 interfere with this pseudo symmetry, e.g. in 1 by showing phenyl π-π stacking only with one of the two independent Schiff base ligands. The copper complexes in compounds 3 and 4 follow roughly these outlined symmetry features of 1 and are all centrosymmetric despite crystallizing in different lattice types. An interesting exception is the Cu-complex in 2 (Fig. 3 ), which is asymmetric. The core of the complex in 2 (Fig. 4 ) resembles in basic geometric features quite well with 1, but due to crystal lattice packing the peripheral phenyl rings behave differently: The twist and twofold π-π stacking between a pair of adjacent Schiff base ligands like in 1 is present only on one side of the complex in 2 (S1, N1, S2, N2 and their carbon and oxygen atoms; Fig. 3), while on the other side the methoxy‑phenyl ring C2’ through C7’ adopts an entirely aberrant orientation disallowing π-π stacking with the N2’ and S2’ bearing ring C23’-C28’; instead of being approximately parallel like in 1 the two rings in 2 are nearly perpendicular to each other. Moreover, intramolecular π-π stacking between phenyl rings of PPh3 and Schiff base occurs only for P1 (C1’-C14’ and C35-C40) while PPh3 of P1’ shows different P-C bond and ring orientations. In this context the non-bonding distance I1-Cu4i = 3.351 Å in 1 has two notably different equivalents of Cu4-I1 = 3.304 Å and Cu4’-I1’ = 3.551 Å in 2. By careful crystal structure refinements, it was found that the Cu-complexes in 1, 2, and 4 show partial vacancies for the Cu4-I2 moieties and their equivalents of 21.2% (1), 10.7 and 18.1% (2), and 19.7% (4), while in 3 such deficiency could not be proved. This feature is interesting as it is in line with the computational studies (vide infra), according to which the step-wise formation of the octanuclear Cu-complexes involves a neutral ring-like hexanuclear intermediate formed by the six Cu atoms, four Schiff base ligands, two I atoms and two PPh3 corresponding to Cu1, Cu2, Cu3, I1 and their symmetry equivalents in 1. In a last step, two Cu4-I2 moieties with a strong terminal Cu-I bond are stepwise added and anchored by two S atoms to give, via a heptanuclear intermediate, the complete octanuclear complex. In crystals an occasional lack of Cu4-I2 moieties appears to be tolerated because latter are buried within the five adjacent phenyl rings of the reference complex as well as by neighboring complexes and the voids they leave could be filled by a suitable co-crystallizing solvent. In case of the very well-refined crystal structure of 1 a CH2Cl2 solvent molecule could be detected and refined which fills the space of most missing Cu4-I2 moieties (refined CH2Cl2 occupancy 16.2% vs 21.2% Cu4-I2 vacancy; cf. ESI). In an unreported crystal of 1 from another synthesis batch, the Cu4-I2 vacancy was found to be 13%. In 2 the Cu4-I2 / Cu4′-I2′ defects of the two inequivalent ends of the Cu-complex were found to be 10.7 and 18.1%, respectively, adding to the geometrical asymmetry of this Cu-complex and proving that there must exist also a heptanuclear species where only one CuI was added to the hexanuclear intermediate. 3.3 Computational studies To investigate the process of the S-S bond cleavage and visualize a possible path for cluster formation, a simplification was performed on the structures. In this context, the (R-CHN˗Ph˗) groups in (R-CHN˗Ph˗S˗S˗Ph-NCH-R) were replaced with the methyl groups (CH3˗S˗S˗CH3) to decrease the size of the molecule and provide the possibility of using a relatively large basis set containing enough polarization functions for the calculations. To propose the key fragments for starting the reaction leading to the formation of the cluster, a reverse engineering method was employed. Fig. 5 a displays the core of the cluster with all C and H atoms removed. Two possible roots are presented in Fig. 5 to reduce the cluster to small fragments (c) and (d) (See ESI for details), and after careful evaluation, the key fragment (d) of pathway (2) in Fig. 5 is selected for the proposed mechanism. Four mechanisms ((A) to (D)) have been speculated for the cleavage of the S-S bond and formation of the key fragments ((c) and (d)) leading to the core of the cluster. The (A) and (B) mechanisms lead to fragment (c) and the (C) and (D) mechanisms end up with fragment (d). (A) and (C) are initiated by an electrophilic attack of one Cu+ ion on one of the S atoms of the disulfide. However, in (B) and (D) mechanisms, the first step involves a concerted process including the electrophilic attack of two Cu+ ions on one of the S atoms of the disulfide bond with simultaneous electrophilic attack on the second S atom by PPh3. The three less likely mechanisms ((A), (B), and (D)) are exhibited in the ESI (Figs. S4–2 (A), (B), (D)) and (C) as the preferred but admittedly speculative mechanism (Fig. 6 ) gives a clear picture of the S-S bond cleavage and consequent cluster formation. A detailed description of the mechanism (C) in comparison with (A), (B), (D) is provided in the ESI. As presented in Fig. 6, the two copper clusters [Cu6{(N)-(μ3-S-CH3)}4(μ3-I)2(PPh3)2] and [Cu8{(N)-(μ4-S)}4(μ3-I)2I2(PPh3)2] are obtained in the proposed mechanism (C). The addition of one CuI to the hexanuclear species gives a heptanuclear intermediate [Cu7{(N)-(μ3-S-CH3)}4(μ3-I)2I(PPh3)2] while the addition of two CuI gives the octanuclear target complex. Based on the X-ray results of 1, 2, and 4, the octanuclear cluster [Cu8{(N)-(μ4-S)}4(μ3-I)2I2(PPh3)2] is in the solid state accompanied by ca. 10–20% of CuI deficient complexes which may be either the hexanuclear or the heptanuclear species or a suitable mixture of both. The stability of the Cu6 and the Cu8 clusters in the solvent (acetonitrile) was investigated by their geometry optimization at the B3LYP/6–311+G(2d,p)/LANL2DZ level of theory. The solvent was modeled by the PCM. A local minimum on their potential energy surface was found for the Cu8 and Cu6 clusters (see Fig. S4.3 in ESI). To obtain information about the cleavage of the S-S bond in the presence of one Cu+ ion in step (II) of the mechanisms (A) and (C), and in the presence of two Cu+ ions in step (I) of (B) and (D) mechanisms, the pre-reactants and pre-products related to this reaction were calculated using MP2(full) method employing the 6–311+G(2d,p) basis set, and the relativistic effective core pseudo potential LANL2DZ [2–4] were selected for (C, N, H and S atoms) and (Cu and I) atoms, respectively. The optimized structures of the pre-reactants and pre-products were used to find the transition state (TS) of this reaction using the QST2 and QST3 methods. Any attempt for finding the TS of the reaction by these methods for (A) and (C) mechanisms were unsuccessful. For further elucidation, the bond length of S-S and S-P were scanned, simultaneously, along the reaction coordinate so that the S-S bond is elongated and the S-P bond is shortened. It is important to notice that this scan was performed as relaxed scan so that at each point of scan, the bond lengths of S-S and S-P were rigid and the remaining bond lengths and bond angles were optimized. Fig. 7 shows the energy profile of this scan versus the steps of scan. As evident, there is no TS structure between the pre-reactants and pre-products which means that the cleavage of the S-S bond is a very fast reaction without TS. The structure related to four points (A, B, C and D) is also shown in Fig. 7. These structures are relaxed structures in the reaction coordinate. Taken altogether, and also considering the transition state structure and its energy profile for S-S bond cleavage and S-P bond formation in the mechanisms (B) and (D) (described in detail in ESI, Section 4, Figs. S4.5 and S4.6), confirm that (C) can be considered as the preferred speculative mechanism for the S-S bond cleavage in the disulfide containing Schiff base and formation of the octanuclear copper cluster. 3.4 Synthesis of triazoles from alkylazide and alkyne catalyzed by Cu8(I) clusters (CuAAC) The catalytic test reactions were carried out in water and by mixing NaN3, the alkyl halide, alkyne derivative and the catalyst, with stirring at room temperature in air (Scheme 3 ). Our initial investigation was directed to optimizing the reaction conditions. Therefore, a series of experiments were carried out under varied quantities of the catalyst (0.1, 0.3, 0.5, 0.7, 1 mol%) and time for a representative reaction of benzyl bromide, sodium azide and phenyl acetylene (Table 3 ). The reaction progress was monitored by TLC until complete consumption of the limiting reagents, benzyl bromide and phenyl acetylene. The best condition for the corresponding 1,4-triazole was obtained using 0.5 mol% of catalyst (nCu = 0.008 mmol), and running time of 90 min. Further increase in the catalyst loading (from 0.5 to 1 mol%) and in the reaction time did not affect the catalytic efficiency (Figs. S5.1.1, S5.1.2.). After drying the reaction mixture under aerobic conditions, the product was extracted first from the solid residue into ethyl acetate. The resulting thiazole was obtained by slow evaporation of the solvent and finally purified by re-crystallization in chloroform. The triazoles prepared by the aforementioned procedure were characterized by melting point measurement, and 1H NMR spectroscopy. The purity of the products was confirmed by comparing their physical and spectroscopic data with those of known samples [64–67]. Representative results obtained for cluster (2), [Cu8{(MeON)-(μ4-S)}4(μ3-I)2I2(PPh3)2], are summarized in Table 4 (for experimental details on catalytic application of clusters (1–5) and characterization of the products see ESI). The recyclability of the catalyst was also surveyed. The durability of the catalytic system was investigated by running several successive experiments on the large scale of 2 mmol of reactants, and a representative reaction of benzyl bromide, sodium azide and phenyl acetylene was carried out. After each cycle, the dispersed colloidal suspension of copper cluster was recovered by washing with ethyl acetate, isolating by centrifuge, and then reusing it in succeeding runs. It is noteworthy to mention that the catalyst 2, [Cu8{(MeON)-(μ4-S)}4(μ3-I)2I2(PPh3)2], was reused up to four consecutive runs, with either the same catalytic efficiency or only a slight decrease in yield (Fig. 8 .). The slight decline in catalytic activity might be due to leaching of the catalyst during the recovery process, or the existence of some dynamic equilibrium at the surface of the catalyst that controls the actual nature of the active sites. To demonstrate the superiority of the as synthesized catalysts, a comparison was made between the efficiencies obtained in the present work with those of other clusters used in the Huisgen [3 + 2]-cycloaddition reactions [27,28,34,68,69] (Table 5 ). The relatively low reaction time and significant efficiency, with remarkably high turnover frequency (TOF = 129 h 1), relative to the other related catalysts, is presumably due to the presence of eight active copper (I) centers in the catalyst. As copper (I) centers are considered to be the most active species in this mechanism, formation of Cu(I)-acetylidine complex by initial coordination with alkyne followed by addition to azide group to give 1,2,3-triazole facilitates the coupling reaction and reduces the reaction time. 3.5 Mechanistic pathway of catalyzed cycloaddition reactions Mechanistically, the presence of 8 copper(I) active sites in Cu8-cluster catalyst plays an active role in the catalytic cycle. As exhibited in Scheme 4 , In the first step the acetylene derivative forms a π-complex with the copper(I) center. Consequently, the pKa of the terminal alkyne CH is lowered [70], facilitating the deprotonation of the alkyne substrate and formation of a σ-bound copper(I)-acetylide complex [71]. Simultaneously, the azide coordinates to the free coordination site on an adjacent copper(I) center. Since the electron density of the coordinated alkyne is reduced by copper(I) [72], the copper(I) acetylide complex undergoes nucleophilic attack by the azide group leading to the formation of the C–N bond and a six membered ring intermediate. The final product of 1,4-disubstituted 1,2,3-triazole is finally formed after release of the copper(I) cluster. This is also consistent with the copper(I) catalyzed azide-alkyne cycloaddition reactions presented in two recent elegant review articles by P.J. Pérez et al. and M. Meldal et al. [35,40]. 4 Conclusions Herein we report the facile one pot synthesis and characterization of a series of octanuclear copper clusters by the reaction of copper(I) iodide and five disulfide Schiff base molecules in the presence of PPh3 in dichloromethane-acetonitrile or chloroform-acetonitrile solution under ambient conditions. The thiolate Schiff base anions, generated in-situ from S-S bond cleavage at room temperature with H2O/PPh3 as reductant, act as bidentate ligands and stabilize the Cu8S4I4 core of [Cu8{(N)-(μ4-S)}4(μ3-I)2I2(PPh3)2] clusters. These clusters are air-stable and their molecular structures have been determined by single-crystal X-ray analyses. DFT calculations have been performed to describe a plausible mechanism of S-S bond cleavage and cluster formation. Presumably, consecutive interaction of Cu(I) and PPh3 with the S-S bond leads to the appropriate fragments that are subsequently involved in the formation of the clusters. These Cu(I) clusters have been utilized with great success to carry out the catalytic synthesis of 1,4-disubstituted 1,2,3-triazoles from NaN3, alkyl halide, and alkyne derivatives (CuAAC reaction) under mild conditions (in water, under air and at room temperature) without any external additive (oxidizing/reducing agent). The relatively short reaction time, high catalytic efficiency (up to 97%) with catalyst loading as low as 0.5 mol%, and good recyclability make these clusters superior relative to the related catalysts. Among these five copper(I) compounds, cluster 2 exhibited the best performance. Author contributions All authors contributed equally to this work. coredata.dc:description: Thiol/disulfide interconversion, catalyzed by metal ions and enzymes, is a fundamental transformation and plays important roles in biological systems. The thiolates, produced in these reactions, are particularly versatile sulfur-containing ligands that can bind to metals or group of metals via a variety of modes and this versatility can lead to the formation of polymeric chains and metal clusters with high nuclearity. Herein, we report the facile one pot synthesis of novel octanuclear copper(I) complexes, [Cu8{(N)-(μ4-S)}4(μ3-I)2I2(PPh3)2] (1–5), by the reaction of copper(I) iodide and disulfide Schiff base molecules (R-CHN˗Ph˗S˗S˗Ph-NCH-R, RMePh = 4-MePh (SB1), RMeOPh = 4-MeOPh (SB2), RMeSPh = 4-MeSPh (SB3), RBrPh = 4-BrPh (SB4), and RFur = 2-furan (SB5)) in the presence of PPh3 in dichloromethane-acetonitrile or chloroform-acetonitrile solution under ambient conditions. Single-crystal X-ray structure analyses of these clusters confirm the presence of Cu8S4I4 core stabilized by the chelating Schiff base thiolate fragment R-CHN˗Ph˗Sˉ produced by the reductive cleavage of disulfide bond, Iˉ, and PPh3. DFT calculations have been performed to describe a speculative mechanism of cluster formation. The octanuclear clusters [Cu8{(N)-(μ4-S)}4(μ3-I)2I2(PPh3)2] (1–5) have been exploited as efficient heterogeneous catalysts for the green synthesis of 1,2,3-triazoles from NaN3, alkyl halides, and alkyne derivatives (CuAAC reaction) under mild conditions.
coredata.dc:title: Novel octanuclear copper(I) clusters [Cu8{(N)-(μ4-S)}4(μ3-I)2I2(PPh3)2] produced via reductive S-S bond cleavage of disulfide Schiff base ligands and their use as efficient heterogeneous catalysts in CuAAC click reaction
